result.title: The Environmental Impact and Ethical Considerations of Big Data Initiatives
result.introduction: The primary argument concerning the environmental impact of Big Data initiatives and the ethical considerations related to data's material presence highlights a significant, often overlooked, problem. This issue involves the ethical implications stemming from the environmental footprint of Big Data, which has largely been neglected by both scholars and policymakers.
result.main_body: The core argument emphasizes the physical reality of data, drawing attention to its material configuration within digital services and the physical space it occupies. This tangible and situated nature of data gives rise to critical ethical questions within the context of the increasingly prevalent Big Data discourses. To address these concerns, the argument suggests that focus should be directed towards three key areas: first, the terminology and vocabulary currently employed when discussing the governance of data initiatives; second, the inherent conflict and tension between existing data initiatives and broader environmental policies; and third, the crucial issues surrounding fair distribution of resources and impacts. By considering these aspects, the aim is to foster more responsible practices in the storage and production of data.
result.conclusion: In conclusion, the central argument posits that acknowledging the material presence of data and its environmental impact is crucial for developing ethical and sustainable Big Data initiatives. A comprehensive approach that scrutinizes language, reconciles policy tensions, and ensures fair distribution is essential for promoting responsible behavior in the digital age.

queries.query: What is the primary argument regarding the environmental impact of Big Data initiatives and the ethical considerations tied to data’s material presence?

hits.title: Big Data, Big Waste? A Reflection on the Environmental Sustainability of Big Data Initiatives
hits.abstract: This paper addresses a problem that has so far been neglected by scholars investigating the ethics of Big Data and policy makers: that is the ethical implications of Big Data initiatives’ environmental impact. Building on literature in environmental studies, cultural studies and Science and Technology Studies, the article draws attention to the physical presence of data, the material configuration of digital service, and the space occupied by data. It then explains how this material and situated character of data raises questions concerning the ethics of the increasingly fashionable Big Data discourses. It argues that attention should be paid to (1) the vocabulary currently used when discussing the governance of data initiatives; (2) the internal tension between current data initiatives and environmental policies; (3) issues of fair distribution. The article explains how taking into account these aspects would allow for a more responsible behaviour in the context of data storage and production.
hits.author: nan
hits.embedding_text:
Big Data, Big Waste? A Reflection on the Environmental Sustainability of Big Data Initiatives Big Data, Big Waste? A Reflection on the Environmental Sustainability of Big Data Initiatives Big Data, Big Waste? A Reflection on the Environmental Sustainability of Big Data Initiatives

This paper addresses a problem that has so far been neglected by scholars investigating the ethics of Big Data and policy makers: that is the ethical implications of Big Data initiatives’ environmental impact. Building on literature in environmental studies, cultural studies and Science and Technology Studies, the article draws attention to the physical presence of data, the material configuration of digital service, and the space occupied by data. It then explains how this material and situated character of data raises questions concerning the ethics of the increasingly fashionable Big Data discourses. It argues that attention should be paid to (1) the vocabulary currently used when discussing the governance of data initiatives; (2) the internal tension between current data initiatives and environmental policies; (3) issues of fair distribution. The article explains how taking into account these aspects would allow for a more responsible behaviour in the context of data storage and production.

This paper addresses a problem that has so far been neglected by scholars investigating the ethics of Big Data and policy makers: that is the ethical implications of Big Data initiatives’ environmental impact. Building on literature in environmental studies, cultural studies and Science and Technology Studies, the article draws attention to the physical presence of data, the material configuration of digital service, and the space occupied by data. It then explains how this material and situated character of data raises questions concerning the ethics of the increasingly fashionable Big Data discourses. It argues that attention should be paid to (1) the vocabulary currently used when discussing the governance of data initiatives; (2) the internal tension between current data initiatives and environmental policies; (3) issues of fair distribution. The article explains how taking into account these aspects would allow for a more responsible behaviour in the context of data storage and production.

Building on literature in environmental studies, cultural studies and Science and Technology Studies, the article draws attention to the physical presence of data, the material configuration of digital service, and the space occupied by data. Big Data, Big Waste? A Reflection on the Environmental Sustainability of Big Data Initiatives Big Data, Big Waste? A Reflection on the Environmental Sustainability of Big Data Initiatives Big Data, Big Waste? A Reflection on the Environmental Sustainability of Big Data Initiatives

This paper addresses a problem that has so far been neglected by scholars investigating the ethics of Big Data and policy makers: that is the ethical implications of Big Data initiatives’ environmental impact. Building on literature in environmental studies, cultural studies and Science and Technology Studies, the article draws attention to the physical presence of data, the material configuration of digital service, and the space occupied by data. It then explains how this material and situated character of data raises questions concerning the ethics of the increasingly fashionable Big Data discourses. It argues that attention should be paid to (1) the vocabulary currently used when discussing the governance of data initiatives; (2) the internal tension between current data initiatives and environmental policies; (3) issues of fair distribution. The article explains how taking into account these aspects would allow for a more responsible behaviour in the context of data storage and production.
